title:
Euclidis megarensis philosophi acutissimi mathematicorumque omnium sine controuersia principis opera a Campano interprete fidissimo tralata Que cum antea librariorum detestanda culpa mendis fedissimis adeo deformia essent: vt vix Euclidem ipsum agnoscere-mus. Lucas paciolus theologus insignis: altissima Mathematicarum disciplinarum scientia rarissimus iudicio castigatissimo detersit: emen-dauit. Figuras centum et vndetriginta que in alijs codicibus inuerse et deformate erant: ad rectam symmetriam concinnauit: et multas necessarias addidit. Eundem quoque plurimis locis intellectu diicilem commentariolis sane luculentis et eruditiss. aperuit: enarrauit: illustrauit Adhec vt elimatior exiret Scipio vegius mediol. vir vtraque lingua: arte medica: sublimioribusque studijs clarissimus diligentiam: et censuram
suam prestitit.
colophon:
Euclidis megarensis philosophi perspicacissimi elemen-torum opus de duabus quantitatibus discreta scilicet et continua. ac earundem proportionibus et proportionalitatibus: ex optima Campani interpretatione. Magistro Luca paciolo de Burgo Sancti Sepulchri Ordinis Minorum sacre theologie professore. Matematiceque discipline cultore feruentissimo die noctuque chalcographis asistente postillis suis oportunis plerisque in locis additis manu propria accuratissime castigatum finit.
Venetiis impressum per probum Virum Paganinum de Paganinis de Brixia decreto tamen publico vt nullus ibidem totique dominio annorum .xv. curriculo imprimat aut imprimere faciat. et alibi impres-sum sub quouis colore in publicum ducat sub penis in dicto priuilegio contentis Anno redemptionis nostre .M.D.VIIII. Klen .XI. Iunii. Leonardo Lauretano Ve. Re. Pu. Gubernante. Pontificatus Iulii .II. Anno .VI.
imprint: A. Paganius Paganinus Characteribus elegantissimis accu-ratissime imprimebat.
title_EN: The works of Euclid, the most acute philosopher of Megara, and of all the mathematicians, without controversy, are translated by the most faithful interpreter of Campanus, which, when previously the fault of the librarians was detestable, were so deformed that we could hardly recognize Euclid himself. Lucas Paciolus, the famous theologian, the most profound knowledge of the mathematical disciplines, the rarest, the most chastened, he cleaned and corrected. He arranged the hundred and fifty figures which in other codes were inverted and deformed, to correct symmetry, and added many necessary ones. He also opened, explained, and illustrated the same in many places, difficult to understand, with commentaries that were truly lucid and erudite. He also eliminatorily expounded the works of Scipio the Vegius, a man of both language: of the medical art: of the most sublime and illustrious studies, and presented his own censure.
colophon_EN: The work of the most perspicacious philosopher Euclid of Megara, the work of the elements, namely discrete and continuous quantities, and of their proportions and proportionalities: from the best interpretation of Campania. To Master Luca Pacioli of Burgo, professor of sacred theology of the Order of the Friars Minor. A most fervent follower of mathematical discipline, day and night, assisted by his copperplate engravers, and in many places added by his own hand, he finishes it with great care. Printed in Venice by the upright man Paganinus of Paganini of Brixia, by public decree, however, that no one may print or cause to be printed there for the whole of the dominion of the years .xv. curriculum. and elsewhere printed under any color in public under the pen in the said privilege, the contents of the year of our redemption .M.D.VIII. Klen .XI. June. Leonardo of Loreto, Ve. Re. Pu. Governor. Pontificate of July .II. Year .VI.
imprint_EN: A. Paganius Paganinus printed with the most elegant characters and with the greatest accuracy.

VTCVNQVE OUR LABOR HAS BEEN CONCLUDED, all these things have been agreed upon, for the no small (which we hope) benefit of students: at the request of the Magnificent D. FRANCISCO Briconnet. If these are kindly accepted, and bring the fruit which we desire: other works of the same author will come to light, God grant success, and the French, Italians, Germans, Spaniards, and English, who are well-disposed to the institution of good letters. We implore prosperity for all of them: and pure and true light of knowledge, for the dignity of the students.
colophon_EN: EUCLID OF MEGARIS, the most brilliant philosopher and mathematician, and the chief of the mathematicians, first from Campanus, then from Theon in the first thirteen, and Hypsicles of Alexandria in the two latter, in the traditions of the Greek philosophers, interpreted by Bartholomew Zambertus of Venice: the fifteen books of the Elements of geometry. title: Die Sechs Erste Bücher Euclidis, Vom anfang oder grund der Geometrj. In welchen der rechte grund, nitt allain der Geometrj (versteh alles kunstlichen, gwisen, vnd vortailigen gebrauchs des Zirckels, Linials oder Richtscheittes vnd andrer werckzeüge, so zü allerlaj abmessen dienstlich) sonder auch der fürnemsten stuck vnd vortail der Rechenkhunst, furgeschriben vnd dargethon ist. Auß Griechischer sprach in die Teütsch gebracht, aigenttlich erklärt, Auch mit verstentlichen Exempeln, gründlichen Figurn, vnd allerlaj den nutz füraugen stellenden Anhängen geziert, Dermassen vormals in Teütscher sprach nie gesehen worden. Alles zü lieb vnd gebrauch den Kunstliebenden Teütschen, so sych der Geometrj vnd Rechenkunst anmassen, mit vilfältiger mühe vnd arbait zum trewlichsten erarnet, vnd in Truckh gegeben, Durch Wilhelm Holtzman, genant Xylander, von Augspurg.
colophon: Vollendet durch Iacob Kündig, zü Basel, in Ioanns Oporini kosten, im jar 1562. auff den dreyßigsten tag des Winmonats.
imprint: Getruckht zü Basel.
title_EN: The First Six Books of Euclid, From the Beginning or Foundation of Geometry. In which the true foundation, not only of geometry (understanding all the artificial, wise, and advantageous use of the compass, ruler, or straightedge, and other tools used for all kinds of measuring), but also of the most important parts and advantages of the art of arithmetic, is written and presented. Translated from Greek into German, properly explained, and adorned with understandable examples, thorough figures, and all kinds of useful appendices, never seen before in German. Everything for the benefit and use of art-loving Germans who presume to be experts in geometry and arithmetic, compiled with great effort and hard work and presented in print by Wilhelm Holtzman, called Xylander, of Augsburg.
colophon_EN: Completed by Jacob Kündig, in Basel, at Ioann's Oporini's expense, in the year 1562, on the thirtieth day of the month of Vineland.
imprint_EN: Transported to Basel.
